description: Demolition of existing conservatory and erection of single storey rear and side extensions, conversion of garage into habitable space, associated changes to fenestration and installation of roof light.
decision_conditions: Development  shall  be  carried  out  in  accordance  with  the  materials  specified  on  the approved plans and on the application form unless otherwise agreed in writing by the Local Planning Authority.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.
The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission.Reason: This is required by Section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990.

The accommodation hereby permitted shall be occupied solely for purposes incidental or ancillary to the occupation and enjoyment of the application property as a single dwelling and shall not be used as a separate unit of accommodation.Reason: The establishment of an additional independent unit of accommodation would give rise to an over-intensive use of the site and lead to an unsatisfactory relationship between independent dwellings.

No development including demolition works shall take place until a tree protection plan has been submitted to and been approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority.The tree protection plan shall demonstrate that any trees on the site which are shown as being retained shall be protected by way of fencing which meets the requirements of BS5837: 2005 "Protection of Trees on Construction Sites" (figures 4 and 5). The fenced area(s) shall be kept entirely free at all times of vehicles, vehicle movements, equipment and machinery. There shall be no changes to the soil level and no excavation of trenches within the fenced areas, no fires lit, no dumping of toxic chemicals and no retained trees shall be used for winching purposes.  If any retained tree is removed, uprooted, destroyed, dies, or is pruned or damaged in a way which negatively effects the amenity or landscape value of the tree, a replacement tree shall be planted in the same location, the size and species of which may be specified in writing by the council.Reason: To prevent unnecessary damage occurring to the trees during building operations, thereby safeguarding the visual amenities of the site in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

No building or use hereby permitted shall be occupied or the use commenced until the details of cycle parking provision has been submitted to and been approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority and thereafter, be kept free of obstruction and available for the parking of cycles only.Reason: To ensure the provision of adequate cycling facilities in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Before the beneficial occupation of the development hereby permitted, any rooflights installed in the roof of the converted garage shall be constructed so that no part of the framework less than 1.7m above finished floor level shall be openable. Any part below that level shall be fitted with, and retained in, obscure glazing to a minimum of level 3 on the standard scale. Any film used to achieve the requisite obscurity level shall be non-perishable and tamper-proof, and shall be replaced immediately in the event that it ceases to result in obscurity to result in obscurity to level 3. Reason: To protect the amenities and privacy of the occupiers of the adjoining residential properties in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Application SiteThe site comprises a detached dwelling situated within a new build development dating from the 1990s on former MOD land.ProposalErection of first floor side extensionThis application follows recently refused application 22/03191/HOU dated 05.12.2022 for the erection of first floor side extension and alteration to roof with hip to gable roof extension which was refused for the following reason:1) By reason of scale, mass and design, the proposed first floor side extension with hip-to-gable roof extension would appear overly dominant, would result in the loss of the characteristic cat slide roof diminishing the visual separation between the application dwelling and No. 35 to the south which would result in an incongruous appearance within the streetscene which would erode the character of the area, thereby conflicting with Policies D3 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012.This reason for refusal would need to be addressed in order for this application to be successful.AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- Fire safety. DesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment: Roof extensions can have a significant impact on the character of the streetscape both in individual cases or through the cumulative impact of several roof extensions within a street. This is particularly true where they are visually prominent within the street. The most appropriate form of roof extension will depend on the style and character of the house on which it isproposed. To address the previous reason for refusal the proposed roof would now be pitched to better reflect the surrounding properties. This would reduce the bulky appearance of the previous Hip to Gable roofline and would also improve the visual separation between the application dwelling and neighbouring No. 35 Coppard Gardens. Officers acknowledge that the proposal would result in the loss of the catslide roof feature but also note the lack of catslide roofs within the area. Overall, the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development. Officers therefore consider the previous reason for refusal has been addressed.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: Due to the existing situation on site, officers consider that it would not appear overbearing and unduly depriveneighbouring occupiers of natural light.  The proposed extensions would comply with current BRE guidance in relation to daylight/sunlight to the nearest windows at both adjoining properties. It is therefore considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has submitted a Fire Safety Strategy.  Officers are satisfied that the proposal adequately meets the requirements of Policy D12(A). Ongoing compliance with the strategy would be secured through conditions, in the event of a favourable recommendation. ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

Positive and ProactiveIn dealing with the application the Council has implemented the requirement in the National Planning Policy Framework to work with the applicant in a positive and proactive way.  We have made available detailed advice in the form or our statutory policies in the Core Strategy, Supplementary Planning Documents, Planning Briefs and other informal written guidance, as well as offering a full pre-application advice service, in order to ensure that the applicant has been given every opportunity to submit an application which is likely to be considered favourably.Building RegulationsYour attention is drawn to the need to comply with the relevant provisions of the Building Regulations, the Building Acts and other related legislation.  These cover such works as  - the demolition of existing buildings, the erection of a new building or structure, the extension or alteration to a building, change of use of buildings, installation of services, underpinning works, and fire safety/means of escape works.  Notice of intention to demolish existing buildings must be given to the Council's Building Control Service at least 6 weeks before work starts.  A completed application form together with detailed plans must be submitted for approval before any building work is commenced.Party Wall ActThe Party Wall Act 1996 requires a building owner to notify, and obtain formal agreement from, any adjoining owner, where the building owner proposes to:- carry out work to an existing party wall;- build on the boundary with a neighbouring property;- in some circumstances, carry out groundworks within 6 metres of an adjoining building.Notification and agreements under this Act are the responsibility of the building owner and are quite separate from Building Regulations, or Planning Controls.  The Building Control Service will assume that an applicant has obtained any necessary agreements with the adjoining owner, and nothing said or implied by the Council should be taken as removing the necessity for the building owner to comply fully with the Party Wall Act. Further information and advice is to be found in "The Party Walls etc. Act 1996 - Explanatory Booklet".Property BoundariesYour attention is drawn to the fact that planning permission does not override property rights, and that if your proposal involves construction on or near the site boundary then you should take appropriate steps to ensure that you have correctly identified the position of the boundary, that you do not build over it, and that any works which affect a neighbours property in any way have the benefit of the appropriate agreement from that landowner. Failure to undertake the above steps may leave you liable to legal action by neighbouring landowners. If you require further information or advice, you should consult a solicitor.Consistency of PlansReasonable efforts have been made to check that the plans submitted for the purposes of this planning application are consistent from one to the next, and that the development hereby approved can be implemented in accordance with all of the plans submitted. Should it transpire that this is not possible and that your plans are flawed, please be clear that it may be impossible to implement this permission, and that any development undertaken which relies on this permission may be unauthorised and subject to enforcement action if expedient.Construction Site NoiseWhen undertaking demolition and/or noisy building work, please be considerate to your neighbours and do not undertake work before 8am or after 6pm Monday to Friday, before 8am or after 1pm on a Saturday or at any time on Sundays or Bank Holidays.  You are advised that the Council does have formal powers to control noise and nuisance under The Control of Pollution Act 1974, the Clean Air Acts and other relevant legislation, and that any works undertaken which impact unreasonably upon the surrounding area may be subject to action by the Council's Environmental Health Department.Definition of Approved in WritingWhere reference is made within the decision notice to a condition applying 'unless otherwise agreed in writing with the local planning authority', please be aware that only a formal application under section 73 or 96a of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (As Amended) is acceptable as a method of said written agreement.Ground Level / Base LevelUnless clearly specified otherwise, the base of the development shown on the approved plans is taken to be external ground level, and not a Damp Proof Course or Internal Finished Floor Level. The external ground level is expected to remain consistent before and after construction of the approved development unless specified otherwise on the approved plans.

Officer ReportApplication SiteThe site comprises a detached dwelling.The site is not subject to any particular designations or environmental constraints.ProposalDemolition of existing rear conservatory, partial conversion of garage into habitable space. Erection of two storey side, single storey rear extension. Rear dormer roof extension including rear juliet balcony and 3 nos front rooflights. Installation of solar panels.Consultations5 properties were notified of the proposal. One representation has been received in support of the proposal.Two representations have been received objecting to the proposal, with comments summarised as follows:- Excessive height or bulk of buildings- Inappropriate design/layout- Loss of light/Sunlight- Privacy- Access or traffic problems- Car park issues- Effects on trees- NoiseAny matters controlled under non-planning laws such as ownership of the site, right to light, building regulations or problems arising from the construction period are not material planning considerations and they cannot be included within the assessment.Any other concerns will be addressed within the report. The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- Fire SafetyCharacter and AppearanceWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The current application is a resubmission of the previously refused scheme ref no 23/00662/HOU. The new element of the proposal is the installation of solar panels.Given the scale, proposed materials and the proposed fenestration to the front elevation, it is considered that the proposed  two storey side extension and conversion of the existing garage into habitable and store space would be in-keeping with the host dwelling and the surrounding area. It is noted that the proposed separation gaps would be of similar width to the existing separation distance to the immediately adjoining properties. As such this element of the proposal would not have a significant impact on the existing street scene. It is acknowledged that installation of solar panels then would not protrude more than 200 mm from the existing roof slope and would not exceed the highest part of the existing roof is likely to fall within the permitted development rights. While the installation of solar panels over the proposed rear dormer roof would not benefit from this fall-back position, given its siting (located towards the rear) and that they would not protrude more than 200 mm from the roof level and in context of the proposed solar panels installed to the front, it is considered that this part of the proposal would not have significant impact on the existing street scene. With regards to the proposed rear dormer roof extension, it is acknowledged that it would be in conflict with Policy Guidance 39, as the dormer would not be set down from the existing roof line by the recommended minimum distance of 500mm. However, given the presence of dormers within similar settings and mass and bulk within the immediate surrounding area, it is considered that the proposed rear dormer roof extension would be in-keeping with the host dwelling and the surrounding area and therefore it would be acceptable. It is noted that the proposed materials would be similar to the existing ones. The depth of the proposed single storey rear extension has been reduced to 4m when compared to the previous application. As such, given the proposed separation distances, depth and the total height of approximately 3m, it is considered that the proposed extension would appear as a proportionate and subordinate addition to the host dwelling and the surrounding area, in accordance with Policy Guidance 33 for detached properties. Considering the following amendments to the scheme such as an omission of the first floor rear extension,  reduced depth of the single storey rear extension and the proposed materials that would be similar to the existing ones,  the revised scheme would overcome the first reason for refusal of the previous application. Officers note concerns raised within written representations regarding the character and appearance of the proposal. However, it is considered that the amended scheme and installation of the solar panels would be in-keeping with the host dwelling and the surrounding area and the proposed development would be in general compliance with the Council's  Residential Design SPD as explained above. Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: It is noted that No 2 Brough Close benefits from the single storey rear extension and rear dormer roof extensions. No 4 Borough Close shows its original layout. The proposed development due to its siting and scale would pass the 45 degree test and therefore it would not result in an unacceptable loss of daylight in relation to neighbouring properties. The scale, mass and bulk of the amended scheme has been reduced (the proposal does not include first floor rear extension and shows reduced depth of the ground floor rear extension), it is considered that the proposal would not result in an overbearing appearance or an undue sense of enclosure when viewed from the adjoining properties and therefore the applicant has successfully addressed the second reason for refusal of the previous scheme. It is considered that the proposed solar panels due to its siting and scale would not appear as overbearing when viewed from the adjoining properties. With regards to concerns raised within written representations regarding potential loss of privacy as a result of the proposed dormer, as there are existing windows to the first floor rear elevation, it is considered that the proposed dormer windows would not significantly change the existing situation. As the proposal would seek to provide a residential extension to an existing residential dwelling Officers consider that there would be no material increase in noise or disturbance for the occupiers of neighbouring properties. It is further noted that the Environmental Protection Act (1990) provides controls to the Council in the event that any noise should occur that could constitute a statutory nuisance. Loss of Car ParkingParagraph 111 of the NPPF, 2021 states that development should only be prevented or refused on transport grounds if there would be an unacceptable impact on highway safety, or where the residual cumulative impacts of development are severe. Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 requires development proposals to have regard to local traffic conditions and highway safety and ensure they are not adversely affected. Officer Comment: It is noted that the existing garage due to its size would not meet the current standards for car parking and therefore it does not count towards the loss of parking space. It is considered that the hardstanding to the front of the dwelling remains of an adequate size to accommodate one off street car parking spaces, therefore the proposal would not result in an unacceptable impact on the local highway network.In relation to cycle parking, Officers note that this provision may be located within the proposed store to compensate for the loss of garage. Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.TreesThe application site is not situated within a conservation area and does not contain protected trees. The proposed works does not include a removal of any trees as declared on the application form. It is noted that the Council's Tree and Landscape Officer raised no objections to the previous scheme.As such it is considered that the proposal would not adversely affect trees situated within the vicinity of the application site. ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.
